channel.title: Romania Travel Blog
channel.description: Diana's complete Travel Guide for Romania

item.title: Danube Delta – the youngest territory of Europe
item.dc:creator: RomaniaTravelBlog
item.description: Danube River is the only flowing water in the world whose distance is measured upstream and not downstream. It is also the second longest river in Europe and the only to cross the continent from East to West. Since antiquity,

item.title: Painted Monasteries of Bucovina
item.dc:creator: RomaniaTravelBlog
item.description: Bucovina ‘The Land of Painted Monasteries’ Bucovina is a region of Romania that still preserves the old ancient traditions unaltered. The name Bucovina comes from Slavic languages and means ‘The Country of Beech Trees’. Traditional costumes are still worn by

item.title: Merry Cemetery – the worlds most cheerful cemetery
item.dc:creator: RomaniaTravelBlog
item.description: The Merry Cemetery The origin of the Romanian people is found in the pre-Christ period. The Romanians ancestors were the Dacians, related to the great Thracian family, occupying a vast territory in Eastern Europe. This people of warriors believed in

item.title: 10 Traditional Romanian foods to try
item.dc:creator: RomaniaTravelBlog
item.description: Romanian cuisine is very complex and diverse, with quite a few differences depending of the specific area which you are visiting. Romanian food has been influenced over the centuries by our neighbors, our invaders and colonists. Some have come and

item.title: Corvin Castle of Hunedoara
item.dc:creator: RomaniaTravelBlog
item.description: Withstanding the harsh passing of time and the fierce attacks of it’s enemies, this Gothic Renaissance structure, has been doing it’s duty as Transylvania’s protector since the XV century. The construction of the castle was commissioned by John Hunyadi (Iancu de Hunedoara

item.title: Prejmer Fortified Church
item.dc:creator: RomaniaTravelBlog
item.description: Prejmer Fortified Church is one of my personal favorite fortresses that really makes the past and turbulent history come to life. Only being there inside the fortress, inside the defense corridors, you can catch a glimpse of the gone by

item.title: 9 Dracula sites to Visit in Romania
item.dc:creator: RomaniaTravelBlog
item.description: Vlad III the Impaler Dracula, it is quite a name and a legend to live up to. Although it is true that myth and history blend to create the portrait of this infamous prince, we cannot take away the fact that

item.title: Mistress of Dracula – Katharina of Brasov
item.dc:creator: RomaniaTravelBlog
item.description: It was Christmas Eve 1455 in the Transylvanian city of Brasov or Kronstadt / Corona as it was called in those days. It was snowing heavily! A few young girls were trying to pull uphill, in the snow, a big sled filled with

item.title: Dracula – The Romanian!
item.dc:creator: RomaniaTravelBlog
item.description: Romania’s national hero When we think of Dracula we almost always think about the made up character, the bloody vampire that always makes a good Halloween story for the kids. But have you ever thought about a brave man, a

item.title: Brasov – touristic capital of Transylvania
item.dc:creator: RomaniaTravelBlog
item.description: My dear Brasov, I probably see this town as often as I see my home town Bucharest and I still love it, still like spending my afternoons guiding tourists on it’s old narrow streets painted with color and architectural flavor
